intro: Ranunculus trichophyllus var. peucedanoides, commonly known as the peucedanoid buttercup, is a herbaceous perennial native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It features delicate, palmately divided leaves and bright yellow flowers with five to eight petals. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in moist, well-drained soils. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The species is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves, which give it its scientific name "trichophyllus."
